In the following slide, we are going to focus on some of the key rules to understand about the financial markets, including the key participants, the objective of these participants, the skills required to be successful as a trader, and some of the skills and processes that First most important thing to understand is who are you playing against? Who are the players in this game or you know in this game of trading? Now there's a number of different players and I've kind of summarized them into five so the first and you know and the biggest players being your pension funds, your hedge funds, your institutions, your banks, these are what we call influential players in other words they can move price around based on the decisions that they make. Okay, now no one, none of us, not myself included, none of us are influential in the market that we can actually manipulate, or not manipulate, but maneuver prices and actually make price go up and down. So straight away, you've got to say to yourself, well, I'm not an influential player. The next type of player is a speculative player. Now, again, a speculative player in this definition, we try and include or more lean towards, again, influential type players. In other words, we're looking at hedge funds that are taking a directional view on whatever market it may be, and they either get stopped out or they don't. They're not holding that product or that asset class until maturity or something like that. So, the next type of player is a speculative player. does not include us as a retail market, as day traders, as short-term traders. We then have the high-frequency traders. Now, again, this might include some of you, some of you that have developed algorithms, this includes you. The important thing to understand with regards to the players that play in the high-frequency is they develop strategies that, one, are very exact and, two, have very specific both risk and reward. And we'll talk a little bit about that later when we go into actually some strategy Then we have the day trader. text: You would fall into this bracket of day traders and then obviously swing traders now The main difference between a day trader swing trader is merely the time frame Over which we're holding day traders a little bit more short term swing trader a little bit more longer term now it's important to understand these players because If you know which player you are and who you're up against, straight away, you're almost going to put yourself in a division of the players. You're going to say, well, I'm one of these players, therefore, this is the type of, you know, not just objective, the skills and the process, but this is ultimately the direction or the path that I need to go down. If you are a day trader or swing trader, I'm going to outline for you now, firstly, what is your objective? Secondly, what are the skills you need? And then third, what is the process? And that's where the meat of tonight's whole periscope is gonna be. So your objective as a day trader slash swing trader, first and foremost, is to develop consistency. Now, what you need to say to yourself when you go through your strategies, when you do your debriefs in a day, when you're thinking of great new ideas, you need to ask yourself, well firstly, I am a day trader or a swing trader. Secondly, what I'm doing right now, this hour I'm spending doing whatever I may be doing, is that ultimately going to get me toward that objective of consistency? Now, the perfect example I like to use is sometimes someone will send me a long timeframe day chart and they'll say, well, what do you think about holding this for the next three weeks for a 10% gain? And I'll say, okay, well, hang on a sec, are you a influential player? Are you a speculative player? Are you able to sit with a massive capital position for a number of days? And the simple answer for 99% of us is no. Okay, so in order to develop consistency you're going to be needing to trade more frequently, okay, and in order to trade more frequently you cannot be taking, you know, one or two or three or monthly type trades. Okay, so you see how we outline the players to the objective. Then the risk management of all of these different players varies very differently. influential player or a speculative player they can sit with massively wide stops we're talking four five ten percent you know stops they'll hedge most of those strategies they have very very different risk management approach to what we do as day traders and swing traders and even high-frequency traders okay of all five of the players high-frequency traders have got the most unique risk management system in that they take very small losers all making a lot more than what they're losing okay then our next objective is to print green every single day okay now that objective differs you know if you're again if you're a swing trader it might be okay to have a few drawdowns for monday tuesday wednesday so long as thursday friday when you do go inside or make money it makes back all of those losses

Now I used to be the one buying it there, buying it there, buying it there selling it there. In other words, if you know what this cumulative delta is at any point, whether it's over the day, the week, the couple of weeks, you've got a very powerful piece of information because you have a good understanding of who's more aggressive between buyers and sellers versus which way is price ultimately going. text: You always tend to get a little bit of a mess about around this line in the sand. It always messes around the other first time. The mistake a lot of people make is they're ultimately buyers at this area. Why? Well, because there's a bias in the market. Okay, so people step in and they buy But what happens is as they're buying the market is struggling to maintain a bit can ultimately what's happening is someone sitting on the other side and passively absorbing the buy Once we then take out that lower pivot. That's the point in which we want to execute. So we want to see some form of sideways distribution just before the break. Once we have the break, when we see a little bit of absorption just before the break from the sellers in this example, we then execute with a relatively tight stop looking for the unwind of the delta. Now stop is very, very simple above the top of the distribution. as a root of thumb potentially extend the low of the day. Once it does that it enters a period of exhaustion and will likely take a break. So we either look for an unwind of the delta or an extension of the low. Okay and that's pretty much how the trade strategy works. That's the basic premise of the trade strategy of a position, a delta position unwind. Now let's look at some of the charts and you'll get a little bit of a better understanding of Again what we can see this is the pound against the dollar 12th of December five-minute rotations again you can use either rotational or time-based here or even in balance you will see it equally well on all three remember the most important thing we're paying attention to is the Delta okay now like I said you need to know your marker you need to know what a big Delta is now that's gonna go contrary to what I'm gonna say but this isn't really Okay, not for the pound. I'd say a large delta for the pound. You're looking somewhere around one and a half to two thousand contracts But it is a relatively good example of a delta unwind So I'm just gonna go through it with you, but bear in mind you do get better examples with much higher cumulative deltas. Now also note You don't necessarily have to go from a high delta So you could have maybe positive 400 delta and when it unwinds it goes to maybe minus 3,000 delta. Okay So ultimately what you do want to see remember the Delta can be slightly misleading in other words as we're coming up here We could be seeing more selling than buying even though prices are rising hence. Why we're not seeing the Delta pick up aggressively, okay, so Again, like I said the community Delta is important But it's not necessary to be all and end on again You know if you observe this pattern within your templates time and time again, you're gonna see what works better than not now
